name: Illustration Guideline
htmlBanner:
Illustration

We simplify complex ideas with our unique illustrations, making them universally clear and memorable, while allowing our brand personality to evolve unexpectedly.

FAQs.html:
FAQs

What color should I use?

When in doubt, default to a black or white color scheme for illustrations.

Where can I use color?

In a few places, mainly brand-forward moments where a dash of color can help lighten the mood or add personality. (Onboarding, Success, Error, and Empty States)

Where can I change colors?

Never, we have specific areas of our product where you can use color and gradients.

How do I create new ones?

When an illustration is needed, check the library before creating something new. Itâ€™s okay to reuse artwork as long as the visual metaphor and meaning make sense.

Usage.html:
Using Illustrations

There are places where illustrations always appear, and places where theyâ€™re used only sometimes.

Empty states

We currently cross launch Meeting Center when a user starts/joins a meeting. To avoid the appearance of duplicate app icons, we use this to signal the in-meeting experience.

Onboarding

Onboarding experiences help users set up areas of the app for the first time, or guide them through new features.

Success / Error

In moments where a tasks is completed successfully or when a system error has occurred, illustrations may be used to further reinforce the message.

Spot illustrations

In rare cases, spot illustrations can be used to draw attention to important areas on a busy page or making complex technical concepts easier to understand.

Choosing Imagery

There are places where illustrations always appear, and places where theyâ€™re used only sometimes.

Reuse artwork

We strongly encourage the reuse of existing illustrations in the library, as long as the visual metaphor and meaning make sense.

Create something custom

If no library illustrations support your needs, a custom illustration can be created.
We suggest combining elements from existing illustrations before drawing something unique.

Usage

Assets

All default illustrations are available in the ðŸ–¼ Illustration Library. â€¨If your illustration requires color, approved gradients are built into the component properties

Components

Style

Resizing

Resizing illustrations will depend on the constraints of your UI. Our recommendation is to pick an illustration that generally fits your canvas size and rescale it if needed. Note: â€˜Peopleâ€™ illustrations are available in all sizes.

01

Identify canvas size where the illustration will sit in the UI.

02

Pick the appropriate illustration size from the library. For instance, if your space is 150px, a large image will not be suitable. Use a small- or medium-sized illustration instead.

03

If needed, adjust the size with proportional stroke scaling enabled. Small illustrations can be resized 60-192px Medium illustrations can be resized to 120-320px Large illustrations can be resized to to 192-480px

Scaling Dontâ€™s

Colors

Do not scale small illustrations > 319px or large illustrations < illustrations below sizes or large illustrations dow to small sizing.

Custom gradient

Do not create custom gradients for illustration.

Color.html:
Color

Monochromaticâ€”Black or Whiteâ€”are the default colors for all illustrations. This promotes accessibility, simplicity, and consistency across our UI

Gradients

Only specific areas of the UI can apply gradients, and all gradients have assigned use cases.
Use cases that can apply gradients:
Empty states
Onboarding
Success / Error
We use color deliberately and specifically for only certain moments of the product.

Empty States

All empty states should always apply the primary gradient for illustration. In special situations, you can use the secondary gradient.

Empty States Dontâ€™s

Colors

Do not apply different gradient to empty states than primary or secondary.

Custom gradient

Do not create custom gradients for illustration.

Onboarding

Onboarding is free to apply the entire gradient set (minus success and error)â€”in any orderâ€”to build compositions. Design note: When choosing gradients make sure your illustrations don't all start with the same color.

Success/Error

Onboarding is free to apply the entire gradient set (minus success and error)â€”in any orderâ€”to build compositions. Design note: When choosing gradients make sure your illustrations don't all start with the same color.

Success / Error Dontâ€™s

Success

Do not apply different gradient to success states, other than ðŸ’Ž IllustraionSuccess.

Error

Do not apply a different gradient to error states, other than ðŸ’Ž IllustrationError.

Applying Color

Applying color to illustrations is fairly simple. With your default illustration picked out: Open up the layers of your illustration component, select â€œapply-style-here.â€ Fill illustration stroke with your gradient from the illustration core style. Note: Some objects in the illustration will not apply a gradient. For those, youâ€™ll have to use a solid color.

Default illustration

Applying gradient

Applying solid

Style Guide.html:
Illustration

The Our design principles heavily influence our illustration style. Seamless Flowâ€¨Vibrant Energyâ€¨Intuitive Focusâ€¨Infinite Identity

Construction

Itâ€™s important that we apply the logo consistently and deliberately to create a coherent experience and ensure the integrity of our brand identity.The Our design principles heavily influence our illustration style.

Principles

Geometric Use geometric shapes (circle, square, triangle, pill).â€¨Rounded Use a cohesive approach to radii and terminals.â€¨Depth Use overlapping lines and changes in scale to create the illusion of depth.â€¨Open Use composition and line to show a starting and endpoint.â€¨Continuous Use connection between elements and the Webex "swoop" to show movement or action.â€¨Simple Use recognizable everyday objects in their simplest form.

Grids

We have three defined sizes depending on an illustration's complexity.

Principles

Stroke weight: 2.5 Container size

Medium

Relative Sizes

Illustration Small

Illustration Medium

Illustration Large

Choosing Size

01 Identify illustration complexity

Be aware of how many pieces from other illustrations you're combining. This determines an illustration's complexity and size.

02 Match with appropriate size

Once built, an illustrationâ€™s size should be clear, but the general rule is:â€¨S/M = 1-2 combined illustrationsâ€¨L = 2 or more combined illustrations

Dos and Donts

Designers are allowed to reuse elements from the existing library

Do not use any unapproved line weight or grid sizes.
